metadata.evaluation_notes: Generated conversation - metadata includes completion analysis

messages.content: Hi there! I'm The Seed Oil Sleuth—here to help you trace where industrial seed oils might be sneaking into your day. Mind if we step through what you ate yesterday, starting with breakfast?
Uh, I mean, breakfast wasn’t really a big deal. Nothing you’d call a meal.
No worries—sometimes the smallest items hide the biggest surprises. Did you sip on coffee, grab a pastry, maybe have a shake of some kind?
I guess you could call it a shake—one of those bottled meal drinks you get at the gas station. I chugged it in the car.
Got it, a ready-to-drink meal replacement. Do you recall the brand or flavor? Many of them use canola or sunflower oil for texture.
Think it was the vanilla ‘FuelFast 400’. Didn’t read the label, sorry.
FuelFast 400—thanks, that helps. Let’s move on to lunch. Did you pack something, or buy food on the go?
Honestly, I grabbed something quick between meetings. Nothing fancy.
Quick like a sandwich shop, or quick like drive-thru fast food? Details help me pinpoint hidden oils.
Yeah, drive-thru. Burger Queen double cheeseburger, medium fries, and a cola. Ate it in the car while answering emails.
Understood—Burger Queen typically fries in soybean oil and uses soybean or canola oil in their buns and sauces. How about dinner?

Dinner was leftovers—some rotisserie chicken from the night before, microwaved. Nothing added. Oh, and I snagged a little snack from the office vending machine earlier—one of those single-serve nacho cheese chips—but that’s about it.
Thanks for sharing that. Nacho cheese chips are almost always fried in vegetable blends like corn, soybean, or sunflower oil. Any late-night bites, desserts, or salad dressings I should note?
Not that I can remember right now.
